content.description: Respect Your Elders climbs the steep corner and flake system on the right side of the main wall. Begin with easy ledges to a series of jugs to a hand-sized cam placement in the top of the initial corner. Clip a bolt at the lip of a small roof, then do a powerful sequence right to establish below the next left-facing corner. Steep jams and laybacks lead to a series of technical moves past two more bolts and then more moderate climbing up a larger corner. A final exposed and thrilling move leads one right around the roof to a ledge with a bolted anchor.
content.protection: Three bolts and a set of cams from very small (gray Metolius) to hand-sized. Bring 2 each in the 0.5" to 1.25" range and a few medium to large nuts.

content.description:
The Gold Card Direct starts at the same place as

The Gold Card Indirect

and takes the striking line up the center of the main wall for a full 30 meter pitch.  Climb through golden, bulletproof granite using a mix of crack and face technique.  At mid-height, place a few bomber pieces, and then step up into the dihedral.  Work out what parts of the crack to use for gear and what parts to use for your fingers.  Consider fishing in a nut above your head before committing to the hard climbing.  Smear, layback, and stem up the dihedral. Clip the fixed piton, and make a delicate move left before the roof.

This route was originally climbed in the headpoint style of rehearsing all of the moves and gear on top rope before getting on the sharp end.
content.protection: Standard double rack of cams and a good set of nuts (BD #8).

content.description:
The Gold Card Indirect takes a striking line up the center of the main wall for a full 30 meter pitch.  Climb through golden, bulletproof granite using a mix of crack and face technique.  At mid-height just before the dihedral, place a piece high, extend it, and traverse left along the sloping ramp.  Make a few committing moves (5.9) to gain the crack system and continue to the top with great gear (fun 5.10).  The anchors are in a great location to top rope

The Gold Card

on your way down.
content.protection: Standard double rack of cams and nuts.

content.description: Climb the thin crack that leads to the large, triangular alcove and past two roofs.
content.protection: The beginning of the thin crack can be protected by a #1 Camalot a red C3 a couple of feet higher protects the crux moves. A three inch piece fits in the pod a little higher. A pin and a standard rack protect the rest of the climb.

climbs.name: Amba
climbs.fa: Chris Barlow with help from Becca Schild and Justin Talbot

content.description:
In certain tribes in Siberia, Amba refers to a mythical wise old man embodied as a tiger.

Like Siberian tigers, routes as good as this one are rare. Amba, the route, climbs a soaring seam on the steep right panel of the Main Wall. Begin up an easy corner with a few loose blocks and trend up and right along seams to a stance near a ledge of the right edge of the wall. A challenging - and slightly runout - sequence back left lands one below a striking crack up the black streak. Technical boulder problems and thin gear lead up this crack, eventually arcing back into the main dihedral of

Respect Your Elders

. One can finish on the easier upper corner of that route, or get full value and bust back right and up the final pumpy climbing on the headwall and making hero moves right to the arete and further to the anchor shared with

Respect Your Elders

.

At the risk of falling into the first-ascentionist-hypebole trap, I wager this is one of the top 5.12 all-trad pitches in the state.
content.protection: A double set of cams from purple Metolius to hand-sized, including small nuts and RPs. Take care protecting the sequence getting established at the bottom of the crack; a #1 Camalot or equivalent can be placed high enough to keep you away from the low angle start.
